Best Mattresses of 2026 According to Consumer Reports

January 17, 2026

The mattress industry is a perfect storm of marketing: vague comfort claims, endless “exclusive” model names, and constant sales that make MSRP feel imaginary. That’s why Consumer Reports mattress recommendations matter. CR doesn’t rely on brand hype or influencer vibes—they lab-test mattresses under controlled conditions and layer in large-scale owner survey feedback to capture how beds actually perform after the honeymoon period.

Their newest roundup of the best mattresses of 2026 highlights top performers across three main categories shoppers actually buy: innerspring/hybrid, foam, and adjustable air. The bigger message is refreshingly practical: there is no single “best for everyone,” but there are mattresses that consistently deliver strong support, durability, and motion isolation for a wide range of sleepers.

Below is a CR Watchdog-style guide to the mattresses Consumer Reports is recommending right now, plus a simple decision framework that helps you buy once—and sleep well for years.

The fast answer: the best CR-recommended mattresses (2026)

If you want the shortlist before you go down the rabbit hole:

Best overall performers by category

  • Best hybrid for hot sleepers: the Casper Snow
  • Best soft hybrid value: the Casper Dream
  • Best ultra-plush hybrid (especially for petite sleepers): the Casper Dream Max
  • Best all-foam “do-it-all” pick: Casper The One
  • Best premium organic foam option: Essentia Grateful Eight Organic
  • Best eco-focused latex foam pick: Earthfoam Organic Medium
  • Best adjustable air beds (overall): Sleep Number p6 Smart Bed and Sleep Number ClimateCool
  • Best value adjustable air bed: Sleep Number c2 Smart Bed (Classic Series)

Now let’s match these to real people and real sleep problems.

Why Consumer Reports’ mattress picks matter (and what they actually test)

Most “best mattress” lists online are built around affiliate commissions. CR’s list is different because it’s built around measurable performance.

Here’s what matters in testing—because it’s what matters at 2 a.m.:

  • Support (spinal alignment): Does the bed keep your spine aligned for back and side sleeping, across different body sizes?
  • Firmness: How soft or firm the mattress actually is on a standardized scale (not the brand’s made-up label).
  • Stability / motion isolation: How much movement transfers when a partner shifts, rolls over, or gets up.
  • Durability: A long-run stress test meant to simulate years of use and check for sagging or performance drop-off.
  • Owner experience: Comfort and satisfaction feedback from a very large pool of real owners.

The result is a list that tends to reward mattresses that are boring in the best way: supportive, consistent, and less likely to become a regret purchase.

The CR Watchdog framework: choose by sleep position and room realities

Before we get into winners, here’s the decision logic that saves you money and back pain.

1) Your sleep position matters more than the brand name

  • Back sleepers usually do best on balanced support that keeps hips from sinking too far.
  • Side sleepers often need pressure relief at the shoulder and hip—too firm can be a problem.
  • Combo sleepers need a mattress that supports alignment without “locking you in.”

2) “Soft” isn’t automatically luxurious

Soft can feel amazing for 10 minutes and then wreck your lower back by morning if the mattress lacks structure. The real goal is pressure relief where you need it and support where you need it.

3) Couples should prioritize motion isolation

If you share a bed, stability is not a bonus feature—it’s sleep quality. A mattress that isolates movement well can be the difference between sleeping through the night and waking up five times.

4) Hot sleepers should treat heat retention as a “must solve”

Some foam beds trap warmth. If you sleep hot, you’re not being picky—you’re describing a real performance issue. If overheating ruins your sleep, it will ruin the mattress no matter how good the “support” score is.

Best innerspring / hybrid mattresses (CR top picks)

Hybrids typically pair coils with foam comfort layers. The coils add bounce and airflow; the foam layers add pressure relief. In practice, hybrids can be a sweet spot for people who want support without the “stuck in the bed” feeling.

Casper Snow — the hot-sleeper hybrid that actually performs

If you’ve ever loved a mattress for comfort but hated it at 2 a.m. because you’re overheating, this is the lane you want. The Casper Snow is highlighted as one of the least heat-retaining mattresses in testing, while still delivering strong all-around performance.

Who it’s best for:

  • People who sleep hot
  • Back sleepers who want strong support without brick-like firmness
  • Side sleepers who want softness without losing structure

Why it stands out:

  • A soft-ish feel that still holds alignment
  • Strong stability, meaning less partner disturbance

Casper Dream — soft, pressure-relieving, and easy to recommend

The Casper Dream is a great choice for shoppers who want noticeable plush comfort but don’t want to gamble on support. This kind of mattress tends to work especially well for side sleepers and petite back sleepers who don’t compress firmer beds enough to get comfort.

Who it’s best for:

  • People who like plush comfort
  • Side sleepers who want pressure relief
  • Mixed sleepers who lean “soft” but still want balance

Casper Dream Max — ultra plush without being a total mystery

The Casper Dream Max is the ultra-plush option. Very soft mattresses are risky if you need firm alignment support, but for petite sleepers—or anyone who wants a deeply cushioned feel—this can be a legitimate “cloud bed” candidate.

Who it’s best for:

  • Petite sleepers who want a sink-in plush feel
  • People who hate firm mattresses and want maximum pressure relief

Watch out for:

  • Some larger back sleepers may prefer a firmer option for consistent alignment

Best foam mattresses (CR top picks)

Foam mattresses can be excellent for motion isolation, but they vary a lot by feel: memory foam “hug” vs latex foam “springy pushback.” The right one depends on how you sleep and how sensitive you are to heat and sink.

Casper The One — the practical all-foam pick

If you want a foam mattress that behaves like a grown-up—not too mushy, not too rigid—Casper The One is positioned as a strong “works for most people” option. It’s a balanced firmness that tends to suit both back and side sleepers.

Who it’s best for:

  • Back sleepers (especially average and petite)
  • Side sleepers who want comfort without going ultra-soft
  • Couples who want good motion isolation

Essentia Grateful Eight Organic — premium organic foam with standout owner comfort

This is the premium organic foam lane, and CR’s list highlights the Essentia Grateful Eight Organic as a strong performer across sleep styles. It’s the kind of mattress that tends to feel “supportive but not harsh,” which is what a lot of people mean when they say they want a bed that feels expensive.

One real-world note: it’s heavy. If you’re moving it into a tight space, plan on help.

Who it’s best for:

  • Shoppers who want a premium foam feel with organic positioning
  • People who want supportive comfort across the whole surface

Earthfoam Organic Medium — latex foam, firm-leaning, eco-friendly

Latex foam is its own category in spirit: it tends to feel more responsive than memory foam, less “stuck,” and often cooler-feeling. The Earthfoam Organic Medium is the firm-leaning, eco-focused option—especially attractive to back sleepers who want structure.

Who it’s best for:

  • Back sleepers who like firm support
  • People who dislike the “quicksand” feel of memory foam
  • Shoppers who care about materials and footprint

Best adjustable air mattresses (CR top picks)

Adjustable air beds let you dial firmness up or down, often separately on each side. They can be excellent for couples who disagree on firmness, or for anyone whose comfort needs change over time. The tradeoff is cost.

Sleep Number p6 Smart Bed — the adjustable all-rounder

The Sleep Number p6 Smart Bed is positioned as a strong overall performer: supportive, stable, and durable in testing. This is the “you want adjustability, but you also want it to feel like a real mattress” lane.

Who it’s best for:

  • Couples who want independent firmness settings
  • People whose comfort preference changes (injuries, pregnancy, weight shifts)
  • Back sleepers who want dialed alignment

Sleep Number ClimateCool — the high-end “control everything” option

If you want adjustability plus temperature features, the Sleep Number ClimateCool is the premium pick. It’s built for people who are serious about sleep comfort and want more active control than “cooling gel foam marketing.”

Who it’s best for:

  • Hot sleepers who want a more engineered solution
  • Shoppers who want the most customizable experience

Sleep Number c2 Smart Bed — the value entry point

The Sleep Number c2 Smart Bed (Classic Series) is the value play: a more approachable way into adjustable air if you want the core benefit—firmness control—without buying the whole spaceship.

Who it’s best for:

  • Couples with different firmness preferences
  • Shoppers who want adjustability at a lower price

How to shop smart (CR Watchdog rules)

Rule 1: Don’t buy a mattress based on 30 seconds of testing

A mattress that feels “amazing” immediately can become “why does my back hurt?” after a week. You need real nights, not a showroom pose.

Rule 2: Be skeptical of “exclusive” models with different names

Retailers often sell near-identical beds under different model names. That’s a feature, not a bug—it makes comparison shopping harder and discounts look bigger.

Rule 3: Look for durability and stability, not just softness

Support and comfort are important. But durability is what separates “great purchase” from “regret in three years.”

Rule 4: Don’t ignore the calendar

If you can wait, the best mattress deal windows tend to cluster around major sale periods. If you can’t wait, focus on getting the right mattress first—saving $200 on the wrong bed is still losing.

Rule 5: Couples should prioritize motion isolation

The “best mattress” is the one that keeps you asleep, not the one with the prettiest marketing story.

Bottom line

Consumer Reports’ best mattresses of 2026 are a strong mix of high-performing hybrids, practical foam picks, and premium adjustable air beds that score well for both lab performance and real-owner satisfaction.

If you want the simplest “buy this and be happy” shortlist:

  • Hot sleepers: the Casper Snow
  • Soft hybrid comfort: the Casper Dream (or the Casper Dream Max for ultra plush)
  • All-foam, broad appeal: Casper The One
  • Eco/latex + firm support: Earthfoam Organic Medium
  • Adjustable air for couples/customization: Sleep Number p6 Smart Bed (or the Sleep Number c2 Smart Bed for value)
  • High-end “everything adjustable” experience: Sleep Number ClimateCool

CR Watchdog note: Mattress pricing is famously fluid. Use this guide to build a shortlist, then buy based on the best real price you can actually get today—not the MSRP anchor on a promo page.

CR watchdog is a fan site started in 2017. We review the reviews to help you find all the best for you and your family.
